subject: Relationships
title: Mourning and Love in the Victorian Age
description: A fast breakdown of Mourning and Love in the Victorian Age for builders.

hook.text: After Prince Albert died, Queen Victoria wore black for 40 years. She slept beside his portrait every night.

buildup.text: Victorian mourning was elaborate: black clothing, jet jewelry, hair woven from the dead lover's locks.

discovery.text: Grief was performative and public. The depth of mourning proved the depth of love in society's eyes.

twist.text: Widows were expected to mourn for years. Widowers were encouraged to remarry quickly. The double standard was stark.

climax.text: The Victorians understood something modern culture avoids: love and death are inseparable. Grief is love's receipt.

punchline.text: The Victorians mourned extravagantly â€” because they loved the same way.
